block.p: 'Friends' Stars Accept Deal That Will Keep Show on Air Under pressure to take a deal worth more than $40 million a year each, or face cancellation of their series, the stars of the NBC comedy ''Friends'' agreed to a deal that will bring the show back for two more seasons.

The six stars of the show -- Lisa Kudrow, Courteney Cox, Jennifer Aniston, David Schwimmer, Matthew Perry and Matt LeBlanc -- accepted $750,000 an episode for the next two seasons as well as a higher percentage of future profits in the show. [Page C8.]

Microsoft Cites AT&T in Defense As the Microsoft antitrust case hurtles toward its conclusion, both sides are drawing on the experiences of the AT&T breakup to support their legal and political arguments, though in some cases the references are inaccurate or incomplete. And a few of the predictions made by Microsoft and its chairman, William H. Gates, mirror arguments AT&T made 20 years ago -- predictions that never came to pass. [C4.]

United Against Outside Interference If Microsoft worries the government, then what about the giant that will be created by the merger of America Online and Time Warner? The Justice Department's antitrust chief, Joel Klein, sees little comparison, although he has no jurisdiction in the case. But there is one similarity: all the companies are on the same side in wanting to fend off government intervention. New Economy. [C4.]

Intel Spinoff for Custom-Ordering Intel plans to announce today that it will spin off a tiny Internet company, Developonline.com, that it hopes will help consumers and business customers custom-order technology products. [C10.]

Catalog Retailers Shine on Web Now that investors have turned their attention to profitability, old-line catalog companies that have built extensive Web operations are stepping into more favorable light. Companies like Lands' End and Hanover Direct are already generating profits from their e-commerce sites. And, thanks to the Web, the prospects for their catalog businesses are improving. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C16.]

Berkshire Hathaway Profit Up 49% Berkshire Hathaway posted a 49 percent increase in first-quarter profit, but its major insurance operations incurred underwriting losses, and the company predicted more of the same this year. [C6.]

Miners Creating Online Marketplace Fourteen of the world's largest mining and metals companies said that they were creating a single procurement marketplace on the Internet, which could cut the industry's $200 billion-a-year supply bill. [C6.]

A Turkish Cartoonist Far From Home From the New York suburb of Scarsdale, Salih Memecan, the political cartoonist for Sabah, one of Turkey's largest newspapers, sends forth a stream of daily cartoons that use deft humor to skewer the politicians and politics of his native country seven time zones away. Mr. Memecan moved 18 months ago. Rather than leaving him stranded and out of touch with Turkish affairs, as friends in Istanbul had feared, he said the distance has given him better insight into the economic and political transformations sweeping Turkey. [C20.]
